Let $A,B\subseteq \{1,\ldots,N\}$ be such that all the products $ab$ with $a\in A$ and $b\in B$ are distinct. Is it true that\[\lvert A\rvert \lvert B\rvert \ll \frac{N^2}{\log N}?\]



This would be best possible, for example letting $A=[1,N/2]\cap \mathbb{N}$ and $B=\{ N/2<p\leq N: p\textrm{ prime}\}$.

This is true, and was proved by Szemer\'{e}di \cite{Sz76}.

In \cite{Er72} Erd\H{o}s goes on to ask whether\[\lim_{N\to \infty}\max_{A,B\subseteq [N]}\frac{\lvert A\rvert\lvert B\rvert\log N}{N^2}\]exists, where the maximum is over $A$ and $B$ with all the products $ab$ distinct, and to determine its value. As noted in the comments to [896] by van Doorn, if the limit exists it must be $\geq 1$.

See also [425] and [896].




References


[Er72] Erd\H{o}s, Paul, Extremal problems in number theory. Proceedings of the 1972 Number Theory Conference
(Univ. Colorado, Boulder, Colo.) (1972), 80-86.

[Sz76] Szemer\'{e}di, E., On a problem of P. Erd\H{o}s. J. Number Theory (1976), 264-270.
